header.title: Millennials Facing Ageism in the Workplace
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Ageism is not just something that happens to older working adults. It is also prevalent for young adults. Millennials are being hit hard with age discrimination, but there is hope. When face these types of aggressive behaviors there are some things that you can do to make your work life more pleasant. . . Human Ragout: http://humanragout.blogspot.com/2017/.... . Instagram: HumanRagout  https://instagram.com/humanragout/. . SnapChat: Jon12213. . Share, Like, Subscribe

commentThread.commentText: This reminds me of white people who complain about being discriminated against. Millennials, in my experience, are incredibly ageist, so I'd say, "Look in the mirror first before judging."

I think as a society in general we need to address ageism. These are all great examples. Agism is most prevalent in the work place. However for some it's also a part of day to day life. Personally in my section of Georgia your ideas and opinions aren't worth anything until your twenty five at least. "Your a child" is something I still hear at eighteen
Ageism?? Millennials?? Thought it was a Gen X and Baby Boomers problem for being over 40.

replies.commentText: Yeah, this is ridiculous. Young people are given many more opportunities in my workplace, while anyone over forty is left out. And, I have many times heard younger workers saying that older people need to "hurry up and retire" to get out of the way of their desires for advancement. Millenials, in my experience, are VERY ageist, so it seems ridiculous to paint them as victims of it.

@Nicole Dean I believe this depends on what field you're in. Im an early intervention speech therapist and I get discriminated against a LOT. I have random teachers disrupt my therapy bsessions, ask me multiple times whether I have a master's degree (which in fact I do) and others who just treat me badly and later ask how old I am so they can laugh in my face. So I would have to disagree with you.

@BeautifullyMade 0627 So you think it's terrible that you get treated that way, but it's perfectly okay when older people are teased, put down (as they are constantly in our culture), and told to "hurry up and retire"? That's called a double standard. Basically, it is only a problem if it effects you, right? Yes, you can be assumed incompetent if you are young, which is wrong, but that is nothing compared to how we marginalize older people. Getting older is almost always seen as undesirable in our culture, while being and looking young forever is the eternally illusive (and pathetic) goal for many. Young people trying to make ageism all about them is asinine and completely self-centered.

@Nicole Dean huh? What are you talking about. I NEVER SAID that it was okay. You tried to downplay reverse ageism saying that we (as young people) don't go through anything and they were given better privileges. All I was saying is that that's not the case for every profession. I suggest reading and thinking before blindly replying.

@BeautifullyMade 0627 Lol. I didn't say anything if the sort. I said right in my response that it was wrong.A simple summation for you: The ageism that young people experience is minor and inconsequential compared to what older people face. Please educate yourself: [LINK]

commentThread.commentText: Ageism only effects Millennials, and is never talked about.

replies.commentText: Are there any legal repercussions for employers that do this?
Are you joking? You really think older people are never discriminated against? That's ridiculous.

commentThread.commentText: such a helpful video! I'm presenting on ageism in the workplace, particularly young professionals, for my graduate school program. This is truly a great start as I begin researching. Thank you! Well done

I have watched a few of your videos in short order. I enjoyed all of them. I found this one compelling. I could hardly wait to see where you would go next, and how you would express it. I shall explore your channel some more.
